Depends how small of a moment! The short answer is “as small as you want”. Around a trillionth of a second after the Big Bang expansion began, the universe was around 10cm in size. (More or less.) But if you go back further, it was smaller. The smallest size that “makes sense” in our current theories of physics is the “Planck Length”, or around 10^-35 meters. Our current physics can’t really deal with matter and energy in a size smaller than that, so physicists start tossing around the term “singularity”. They will sometimes say that in the early universe (or in a black hole) matter is contained in a zero-dimensional point. This is obviously nonsense, since the density of such an object would be (whatever mass)/( zero volume), which is mathematically illegal. That’s what a singularity is – it’s a term from mathematics used to refer to a situation where a function asks you to divide by zero. Sometimes physicists will talk about a singularity as if it’s some kind of physical object. It’s not. It’s a pointer to the fact that our theories are no longer giving us reasonable answers.

What we call the visible universe (all the stuff that we can see, all the way out to the microwave background) was tiny, subatomic in size. However, if it is true that (as the theory predicts) our universe is spatially flat, the whole universe is spatially infinite and has always been spatially infinite, even in the earliest moments of its existence.

After the inflation epoch ended at seconds, what is now our observable universe was only about 30 centimeters across (with a pretty big uncertainty). Pretty cool, right? At 380,000 years when the cosmic microwave background was emitted it was a billion times smaller in volume than today.
